Award.AwardTitle: Science of Broadening Participation: Promoting the Recruitment of Girls into Science, Technology, and Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a research project that studies how improvements since 1965 in scientific and technical education for a broader range of young people has grown into what is currently a national priority. The study will explain in detail how, when, and why this commitment to diversity developed, permanently reshaping our modern cultures of science, engineering, education, and child-rearing. Major outcomes include an academic book, Recruiting Engineer Jane and Astrophysicist Amy: American STEM Advocacy for Girls, 1965-Present, plus scholarly papers, public presentations, a textbook, and museum exhibit. Analysis is primarily grounded in history, but draws on and informs our understanding of present-day outreach in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM).

Although the project being supported focuses on the evolution of campaigns for girls, the account to be developed will provide insights into parallel efforts to promote access for other under-represented groups, adding historical dimension to ongoing discussions of diversity in STEM. The researcher conducting the study has extended research experience in the history of science and technology, science-policy studies, and the broad context of modern U.S. history. Her study draws on a wide range of reports, letters, administrative records, and other documentation from individual actors and organizations, such as the National Science Foundation, National Academy of Engineering, American Association of University Women, and Girl Scouts. Beyond assessing this wealth of data, this initiative explores new territory by conducting central case-studies and several dozen unique oral-history interviews with key figures in the movement to open STEM to girls. The researcher will conduct oral-history interviews and archival research across multiple libraries and archives. She will deliver talks to both academic and general audiences, mount a museum exhibit on STEAM (the A denotes the Arts) and diversity, and develop K-12 curriculum packets and exhibit-visitor materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research explains one of the most distinctive developments in science and engineering from 1965 to the present, the way that improving scientific and technical education for a broader range of young people grew into a national priority. It details for the first time how, when, and why this commitment to diversity developed, permanently reshaping modern cultures of science, engineering, education, and child-rearing. Analysis is primarily grounded in history, but draws on and informs understanding of present-day outreach in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Analysis here focuses on the evolution of campaigns for girls, but also offers insight into parallel efforts to promote access for other under-represented groups, adding historical dimension to ongoing discussions of diversity in STEM.

In recent years, political leaders, business heads, and many organizations, including the NSF, NAE, AAUW, Society of Women Engineers (SWE), and others, have often stressed the need to bring more young women into STEM. Around the country each year, K-12 educators, colleges, museums, school districts, science centers, and government agencies pour time and energy into hundreds of programs aimed at increasing STEM diversity, funded by corporations and other advocates. Yet back in the 1960s, many Americans ridiculed or dismissed any idea that women could handle rigorous science and engineering, associating demanding subjects and technical progress with white masculinity. The past five decades have revolutionized both professional and popular ideas about who can and should enter STEM. Despite the scope and significance of initiatives today to promote girls’ enthusiasm for science and technology, we have no systematic analysis yet of how this dramatic shift happened. The story is complex, both reflecting and driving escalating concern for young women’s well-being, changing gender relations, and new interpretations of the nature of scientific and technical work. This study thoroughly details the forces that opened STEM dialogue about diversity and also offers historical perspective on remaining obstacles facing women, minorities, and other constituencies. This research represents a unique multidisciplinary combination of history of science and engineering with the history of education, social history, women’s studies, and modern economic, political, and social dialogues about STEM and gender.  

This grant also supported the training of one graduate student in the Iowa State University Department of History, who worked closely with me in locating, collecting, and organizing primary-sources regarding girls’ STEM education and outreach programs. Being able to familiarize herself more deeply with ISU's information sources and with resources in the history of science field deepened her confidence as an early-stage graduate student and strengthened her foundation for doing archival research for her own master's thesis, which she completed and successfully defended in spring, 2020. 

 During the period of this grant, I published one peer-reviewed article in the journal Engineering Studies (2019) and one invited chapter in the book Growing Up America: Youth and Politics since 1945 (University of Georgia Press, 2019). The longer-term plan here is still to publish a book on the history of the "girls' STEM movement," as I term it, for which these articles serve as a useful foundation. This book should interest scientists and engineers, historians of science and engineering, K-12 and college STEM educators, plus parents and members of the general public who care about opportunities for daughters and other young women in STEM fields.

Other outcomes here during the grant period include three conference papers (presented at the 2018 History of Science Society meeting, the 2019 Society for the History of Technology meeting, and the 2019 International Society for the History, Philosophy, and Social Studies of Biology biennial meeting), and one scholarly colloquium (at Johns Hopkins University), and four invited public lectures (at Georgia Tech, Colby College, and the University of Illinois).

 

Finally, I initiated and helped bring to completion two museum exhibits related to this research, in two different states, aimed at two different audiences. The first exhibit, "Full STEAM Ahead: Creativity, Beauty, Science, and Engineering,"  ran from April to June, 2019, at Iowa State University's art museum. For this exhibit, I selected objects for displays linking science and engineering to art, and I helped plan, develop, and edit a custom video featuring eight professors discussing how their research showcases creativity, beauty, and diversity.  The second exhibit should reach an even wider audience, at the National Toy and Miniature Museum in Kansas City. Though delayed by COVID-19, my exhibit, "Bridging the Gender Divide: Toys That Build STEM Skills," is now open and scheduled to run from July 15, 2020 through Sept. 5, 2021. By contrasting older construction toys aimed at boys (such as Erector Sets) with recent development of toys aiming to encourage girls in STEM (such as Goldieblox and Roominate), the exhibit encourages young museum-goers, parents, and other visitors to think about the history of gender in STEM  through the popular medium of toys.
